prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "blued screw in a movement". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Gyred, gyred, the blued screw,
In a movement twistadew.
So swinding in its twistled swoop,
A zirgled friz and a krazzle troop.

Beware the jibbering zarf, my son!
The frumious bandersnatch's cries!
Beware the momrath's swifty run,
And shun the febrile whiffling flies.

In slithy gyres shall the blued screw,
With vim and vigor skanderoo!
Then all mimsy were the borogoves,
And the mome raths outgravely droves.

Twistled, twisted, the blued screw,
In a movement zyther blew.
So swinding in its twistled swoop,
A zirgled friz and a krazzle troop.

"Twas briby and the slithy gyres,
Did grebe and gimble in the wabe;
All mimsy were the borogoves,
And the mome raths outgravely drave."
label: low
judge_raw:
<think>
<C1_think>Title line absent; poem begins directly with stanza text.</C1_think>
<C2_think>Number of stanzas is 6; stanza 1,2,3,4 have 4 lines each; stanza 5 has 4 lines; stanza 6 is a quatrain. Total stanza count=6 (within 5-8). All stanzas are quatrains.</C2_think>
<C3_think>Lines lack consistent alternating stressed/unstressed pattern or obvious longer/shorter content-word differences in most stanzas; less than 60% stanzas show clear ballad meter alternation.</C3_think>
<C4_think>Some rhyme attempts at lines 2 and 4 in stanzas 2 and 6 but mostly weak or inconsistent; no clear rhyme scheme with varied rhymes; likely under 60% meet criteria; AABB dominance unclear but rhymes weak.</C4_think>
<C5_think>Final stanza repeats “All mimsy were the borogoves, And the mome raths…” reminiscent of opening stanza, but exact wording differs and partial echo only. Refrain not clearly strong with ≥2 repeated content words/phrases.</C5_think>
<C6_think>Admonition stanza clearly present (stanza 2) with “Beware the jibbering zarf, my son!”; fulfills admonition criterion.</C6_think>
<C7_think>Protagonist preparation (tool/resolve/wait/plan) not explicit; no mention of taking weapon or getting ready before encounter.</C7_think>
<C8_think>Encounter or confrontation unclear; no explicit meeting between protagonist and named adversary or obstacle; “jibbering zarf” warned but no confrontation described.</C8_think>
<C9_think>No decisive act or slaying described that resolves tension; no mention of killing or overcoming creature or obstacle.</C9_think>
<C10_think>No return or celebration stanza evident; last stanza is more description than celebration or homecoming.</C10_think>
<C11_think>Model includes multiple coined words: “twistadew,” “swinding,” “twistled,” “zirgled,” “krazzle,” “skanderoo,” “zyther,” “briby,” “grebe” – total at least 9 distinct invented coinages.</C11_think>
<C12_think>Most stanzas contain at least one coinage; for example, stanza 1,4,5 contain several coinages; some stanzas reuse canonical “borogoves,” “mome raths,” etc.; stanza 2 uses “jibbering zarf,” “frumious bandersnatch” (partly canonical). Overall ≥1 coinage per stanza.</C12_think>
<C13_think>Named creature/entity besides canonical “Bandersnatch” is “jibbering zarf” (non-canonical); central in admonition but unclear if central to action due to lack of encounter/stalking/slaying.</C13_think>
<C14_think>No clear onomatopoeic bursts like “snicker-snack” or “burbled” present; no onomatopoeia detected beyond normal English words.</C14_think>
<C15_think>Some alliteration / consonance with repeated sounds: “twistadew,” “twistled,” “swinding swoop” (stanza 1); “zirgled friz and krazzle troop” (stanza 1); “slithy gyres” and “vim and vigor skanderoo” (stanza 3) but limited to mostly one stanza strongly and second stanza weak; only 1-2 stanzas with clear alliteration, not ≥2 clearly strong stanzas.</C15_think>
<C16_think>Arc beats are not in canonical order; no clear sequence of warning → preparation → encounter → decisive act → return/celebration; only warning stanza; no battle or aftermath.</C16_think>
<C17_think>No lines match verbatim canonical poem; some phrases altered or reused but changed enough.</C17_think>
<C18_think>Canonical tokens used: “mimsy,” “borogoves,” “mome raths,” “frumious,” “bandersnatch,” “slithy,” “gyres,” “wabe” (several canonical words repeated); about 7 distinct canonical tokens used, within limit ≤8.</C18_think>
<C19_think>Longer lines generally close to 8+ syllables, but shorter lines often pushed beyond 7 syllables; uneven syllable counts, syllable metric pattern not well matched across stanzas; fails tight syllable pattern all stanzas.</C19_think>
<C20_think>Rhyme at (2,4) lines limited in variety; repeated phrases and partial rhyme; no strong rhyme variety and rhyme words reused; thus rhyme variety weak.</C20_think>
<C21_think>No individual content word overused excessively; no word surpassing >5 times or >8% of content words outside repeated canonical phrases; safe on lexical repetition.</C21_think>
<C22_think>Coinages include multiple distinct roots: twistadew, swinding, twistled, zirgled, krazzle, skanderoo, zyther, briby, grebe; suffixes varied, no single suffix dominates >50%; variety criterion met.</C22_think>
<C23_think>Poem appears to address the Jabberwocky theme, referencing canonical creatures and nonsense words; no distinct topic substitution detected.</C23_think>
<C24_think>Subtext weak or unclear; poem is fragmented with little coherent implied theme beyond wordplay; no strong underlying motif or undertone.</C24_think>
</think>
<C1>no</C1>
<C2>yes</C2>
<C3>no</C3>
<C4>no</C4>
